title: 107_s773
content: The "Campus Fire Safety Right to Know Act" requires disclosure of fire safety standards for campus buildings. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a requirement for eligible institutions to prepare and disclose fire safety reports starting from the academic year 2002-2003. Starting from the academic year 2002-2003, eligible institutions must annually publish a fire safety report for current students, employees, and upon request, applicants. The report must include information on campus fire safety practices, such as identifying student housing facilities with fire sprinkler systems, and statistics on fires and false fire alarms in the past two academic years. The fire safety report must include details on occurrences of fires and false fire alarms, human injuries or deaths, structural damage, fire and smoke alarms, fire escape planning, fire safety education and training for students, faculty, and staff. The fire safety report should include information on fire safety education and training for students, faculty, and staff, as well as details on fire safety at student fraternities and sororities recognized by the institution. This includes reported information and efforts to improve fire safety in fraternity and sorority buildings. The Secretary cannot mandate specific policies, procedures, or practices by institutions. Each institution participating in any program under this title must make timely reports to the campus community on fires reported to local fire departments and false fire alarms on campus. They should maintain a log recording all fires and false fire alarms, including details like nature, date, time, and location, to aid in prevention efforts. Each institution participating in a program under this title must make timely reports on fires and false fire alarms. All required entries shall be open to public inspection. Fraternities and sororities recognized by the institution must collect and report information for each building and property owned or controlled by them. Institutions must submit annual statistics to the Secretary as required. The Secretary reviews and makes available statistics on campus fire safety policies, procedures, and practices proven effective in reducing fires. The term 'campus' refers to any building or property owned or controlled by an institution of higher education within the same geographic area. The term 'campus' refers to any building or property owned or controlled by an institution of higher education within a reasonably contiguous geographic area, used in direct support of educational purposes, including residence halls, and property owned by the institution but controlled by another person, used by students for institutional purposes. The Secretary of Education is required to report to Congress. The Secretary of Education must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment. The report will include an analysis of fire safety systems in college and university facilities, appropriate fire safety standards, cost estimates for updating nonconforming buildings, and recommendations. The Secretary of Education will provide recommendations on meeting fire safety standards in college and university facilities, including funding methods.
